captions.text:
Good morning John, you may have heard that
we are in the middle of something of an environmental

crisis? Climate change, Oil spills, Dead zones,
Garbage patches, Meltdowns, Mass extinction.

The root of all these problems is people.
Us. You and me and Jacques Chirac and everyone

watching this video and everybody they know
and everybody who's ever made a movie with
Kevin Bacon.

The environmental crisis that we currently
inhabit, was created to satisfy the needs,

or at least the whims, of humans. So the question
becomes given the marvelous beauty and tremendous

value of these biological systems that, as
far as we know, are unique in the universe,

are we worth it? Would the world be better
off without us? Is humanity and our culture

our civilization our technology just an asteroid
bearing down on the planet destroying everything

in its path? Basically 'Should I feel bad
for existing?' is what I'm asking.

My suspicion is that most people don't spend
a lot of time worrying about this, but I do

and I've come to the conclusion, after years
of thinking about this, that we're worth it.

I might be biased towards humans, being one
of them and all. But in the same way that

the complexity of the natural world is beautiful
and marvelous and as far as we know unique

so is the technological world and the psychological
world and the sociological world. There's

something really marvelous about humanity
that is really easy not to notice when you're
inside of it all the time.

I've heard people say 'Yeah, sure humanity
is the smartest, but cheetahs are the fastest,

blue whales are the biggest and barnacles
have the longest penises. It's all completely

subjective, it's about what trait you choose
to put value on.' But I don't buy that. I

think those people probably know that there
is something different, something special,
about people.

The scale on which our brains have allowed
us to create. Everything from tiny little

ideas to the Burj Khalifa. We create! We've
created cultures and atomic theory and Bridget

Jones's Diary and Star Trek and Honky Tonk
Music. All of these tiny units of seemingly

ceaseless complexity and order, it's extremely
valuable and unique.

We are not an asteroid, even if in the end
and I hope we don't, we have the same effect

on the biodiversity of the planet. Witnessing
the scale humanities achievement and our creation

and the interaction of that with the natural
world and the way that it allows us to understand

the natural world, that's the closest I get
to spiritual. It fills me with awe and joy

and wonder and pride. Yeah, we have done things
for which I will never forgive us, but we
create more than we destroy.

That's gotta be the goal, to destroy less,
and to create more. To increase awesome and

decrease suck, that's- that's what I believe
in. That is what I believe, and that, I think,

humans ultimately are pretty good at. And
are getting better at. John, I'll see you
on Tuesday.

Endscreen! Few things going on. One: CrashCourse
Psychology starring me, has just launched

on youtube.com/crashcourse, if you wanna check
it out, we're going to be using our minds,
to explore our minds.

Two: I promise this time I'm coming back to
hankgames, cause it's been johngames for a

long time. Multiple videos per week, including
pikmin 3 and hank and katherine play super
mario brothers U.

Three: If you haven't heard already, DFTBA
Records, our merch company, needs a bigger

warehouse. So we're leaving our old warehouse
and moving to a new one, and we would rather

not take all of our old shirts with us. So
we're selling them for ten dollars apiece,

which is about half of what they usually cost.
A bunch of them have sold out but there are
many more that are not sold out.

There's a link in the description to all of
the things that are on sale, or just go to

dftba.com. If you've been holding back, this
is the time. Okay! Thanks for listening to

me rationalise why humans should exist. Okay!
That's it, for real this time.

comments.author: Keegan Harris

comments.text:
I'm not disagreeing with you, but I'm just wondering, does this world need 
our creativity? The way I processed this is that the environment had paid 
great costs to our ability to create, and the natural world...well it 
hasn't really gotten any benefit from our creativity (I mean, we created 
the zoo. And drove MANY animals to extinction..all due to our ability to 
create, we've created things to make human lives easier which is great! I'm 
amazed by the human mind it's basically a whole new universe in there). But 
I mean, are we worth it? We think our creativity is worth it because we are 
human, but in the environmental/natural world/earth's perspective, I 
honestly DONT KNOW if we are worth it or not. Perhaps it's not a real 
question, we are here because we are, science, chance, luck. Maybe we are 
going to destroy earth completely eventually, and then finally, human race 
will go extinct too. Then earth will finally become a dead planet, or when 
the sun explodes the earth will be burned into ashes and particles. And 
that's it. Of course we will want to live as along as possible and should 
all try to destroy less and create more, but if we don't, we will just need 
to suffer the consequences of that. ﻿

comments.author: tyler garrett

comments.text:
+tyler garrett Well, not exactly. And it certainly isn't very realistic 
that we and all of our things would all just disappear. So that isn't even 
really an option. And if we all were to drop dead, all at once, in the 
middle of what we're doing, with all of our factories and cars running, 
that would create WAY more problems than it would solve. We have made a 
huge ton of mistakes, of course. Not all of them can be fixed or reversed, 
but some of them can, and only we can fix them. We can't bring species back 
from total extinction, no. We can, however, save some of the species that 
we've driven to near extinction. We can replant some of the forests we've 
cut down and build upwards instead of out to minimize the sprawl of our 
impact and restore the habitats that otherwise would have been destroyed. 
And not everyone is ignorant; there are some brilliant, wonderful, 
hardworking, dedicated people out there who are working to fix our 
problems. Please, if you listen to nothing else that I'm saying, please 
read the book called "Hope For The Animals And Their World: How Endangered 
Species Are Being Rescued From the Brink" by Jane Goodall. This was the 
book that brought about my slightly more optimistic paradigm (before, I 
believed that humans should go extinct, too) and made it so I decided that 
the one thing I accomplish before I die is going to be to save a species 
from extinction. I will be working in captive breeding programs after I 
graduate from college, and I will be working with other people who care 
deeply about the Earth and want to fix it. Because there ARE people like 
that. The problem is NOT that people won't care. They just aren't educated 
enough to care. They're taught that humans have the right to live on Earth 
as the dominant species either because they think that we've earned it 
somehow or that the privilege is bestowed by a God. But there IS HOPE. And 
I really hope, for your sake and the sake of the Earth, that you can learn 
to see it. Because maybe if you can, then other people who feel the same 
way can. And if they can, then maybe there's hope for us all.
comments.author: Marissa Oslick

imagine and write about fixing the world, we can do it.

comments.text:
So just a note here: This comment hasn't got much to do with this video. Or 
anything. I don't know yet, I don't think that far ahead when I'm 
commenting. But anyway, it's more about the Green brothers, and this 
channel, in general. I've only just subscribed to this channel, and I, 
quite frankly, think that this channel, and you two people, are amazing, 
and you are something that I aim to become, in the end. You have the 
intelligence and charisma to realise and reasonably discuss topics that 
need to be discussed. But what you also have, which most other intelligent 
and charismatic people don't, is the PASSION and the sense of moral good. 
And I really admire you both for that. You have definite, informed 
opinions, and you aren't afraid to state them. And that gives you many, 
MANY epic points in my book. So keep it up guys. You're epic.

Okay, so that didn't include anything about this video. Oh well.﻿

comments.text:
Lots of comments below, so this has probably already have been mentioned, 
but is worth repeating:
It is true that we humans are gifted with creativity, however, we use that 
gift for our own selfish needs. The one motivation we have is to create 
something that makes our lives easier; more comfortable and less stressful. 
Often times, at the expense of Mother Nature. Besides, the world has 
existed just fine for a couple billion years before we appeared on the 
scene. We are just "unnecessary". It's the painful truth, but the truth 
nevertheless.

Off I go now to walk blindly into incoming traffic. Laterz...﻿

comments.author: The Optimist Vibe

comments.text:
@Hank Green If this kind of scientific pantheist thinking is what gets your 
spiritual dander up in a fury, it's not without reason (in my humble 
opinion).  While I deplore the damage that our species has wrought upon our 
planet, your asteroid comparison brings up an interesting sidebar:  Our 
planet has undergone multiple extinction-level events  (only some of which 
were asteroid-catalyzed or -based).  The human species, with our 
perceptions of its wild variations in form and ability, may in fact be a 
programmed facet of the biosphere.  I'm not going to go into 
bio-determinism, but cheers on yet another amazing video from the 
vlogbrothers, my spiritual siblings.  Please continue the vlogbrothers, 
Mental Floss, and SciShow, as I am triple subbed and going to 
subbable[dawt]com on my next paycheck. ﻿
comments.author: arcsomniac

comments.text:

individual and macro level, is worth it.﻿

comments.author: Gino Tovar

comments.text:
This is actually something I've been thinking about a lot, and while I 
agree on some points Hank made, I feel like playing the devil's advocate 
here, so just have the patience to find out why I think the opposite...

1. Why do we think humans are more worth than other forms of life? If you 
were caught in a burning building and had to choose between saving a human 
you hate or a pet you love, you will always choose the human, right?

This probably is just a by-product of evolution. We want to reserve our 
genes, because hey, making babies is the ultimate meaning of everything, 
right? Well, saving someone who looks like you also saves your genes, as 
you have more genetic information in common with a human than a dog, for 
example.

So could we deduce that feeling this way about human life is just a stone 
age idea of species-oriented racism? Or species-ism... :D This is backed up 
by the thought that we, as humans feel more empathy and connect better with 
people who look like us and also might discriminate against others, who are 
different. (e.g. racism)

Is this really a logical way to think or is this just based on some 
evolutionary advantages you get for humanoid-favoritism? 

2.If someone thinks that our intelligence makes us "special" then what 
about a small thought experiment? Imagine a creature that is as far away 
from us intellectually as worms are, but in the other direction. An alien 
race that has mastered space travel and is superior to us in every way. 

Would it be okay for this alien race to treat you as they wish and take 
advantage of you? Of course not! So why is it ok for us to do so to others?
It's our viewpoint that makes our perception skewed, we wouldn't use the 
criterion of intelligence to determine importance if we weren't the most 
intelligent race we knew.

Just think about how you measure your own "worth" (I'm just using this word 
for the sake of the argument, not because I think a persons worth can be 
measured in this way..) You would obviously put more value on the 
characteristics that make you special. If you're athletic, you're more 
likely to value athleticism, or if you're smart, you will value yourself 
based on that.

It isn't like our achievements don't matter, it's just that we would find a 
way to think the best about ourselves no matter what.﻿
comments.author: Ella Jonninen

comments.text:
When people say humanity is so bad, and we are destroying the planet, they 
fail to take into account that most of the world's population is starving, 
and oppressed. Even if everyone in the world does their part to help the 
planet (recycling, not driving so much, etc. things which everyone should 
be doing), the impact is still very small when you have multinational 
corporations deforesting the amazon at 100's acres per second, or dumping 
massive amounts of waste into the ocean. It's a small portion of humanity 
that's destroying the planet for everyone. And they're the same people who 
make the majority of humanity starving and oppressed.﻿

comments.text:
+Quiet Hero
That's not a fair comparison. I'm not talking about killing out of 
necessity, the way nature goes, I'm talking about killing out of spite, 
ambition, and arrogance. I have no problem eating steak - I do have a 
problem with deforestation and hunting for sport.
Cows eat grass because their designed to eat grass in order to survive. 
Humans kill animals and destroy ecosystems because we feel like it.

comments.author: Quiet Guardian

comments.text:
I think everything can be done in moderation, and humans are definitely 
getting better with that. I don't think we should save every species in 
danger of extinction. Extinction is a natural occurrence, and we are like 
any other predator. But, because of our large impact on the planet, we 
should be aware of our own power so not to cause exponential growth in 
death.

comments.author: SmartAssassin0

comments.text:
The ethical issue isn't man's inhumanity to non-human nature because that 
doesn't have a value without man to put a value on it. If we didn't exist 
or stopped existing nature and life would carry on regardless, even if it 
had to start again from single celled life. At worst we are no different 
than any number of natural disasters that have struck the earth repteadly 
since the advent of life.

It's man inhumanity to man. I struggle to think of some great achievement 
that isn't built on a pile of corpses, people who will never live again 
because souls are bullshit. I kind of feel it is my answer to the Femi 
Paradox: If aliens found us they wouldn't want anything to do with us.

That said Orangutangs are obviously sentient if not as smart as humans, so 
we should preserve them.

Hey, I like baby orangutangs okay?﻿
comments.author: SerPinkKnight

comments.text: I'm in love with your color coordinated book shelf. ﻿
comments.author: Katie Kreitman

comments.text:
You speaking directly from my heart with your very first question: Are we 
worth it? Should I feel guilty for existing? Only I don't come to the same 
conclusion: Yes, humans create. But all our creating only serves ourselfes. 
In the end, the point that urks me most is: We are the number 1 reason for 
suffering on this planet. All our creations, as magnificent and awesome 
they might be, don't cease all that suffering.  All those extinct animals, 
all those 50 billion annualy slaughtert animals, all those exploited soils, 
they don't get anything out of our creations. So we live off this planet, 
destroying it in our way, to create things that only we can enjoy. I don't 
think this is just.﻿

comments.author: TheSmileyAngelXD

comments.text:
If I were an alien invader looking to colonize earth probably the first 
thing I would do is enslave all of humanity and kill the remainder to save 
Earth's environment and biodiversity.  When asked to justify this atrocity 
I would simply point out that if I did not intervene as I did there was a 
95% chance that humanity would annihilate itself along with no less than 
50% of the species that currently inhabit the Earth within the next 150 
years in such a way that would render the Earth mostly uninhabitable to my 
species for the forseeable future.  And that the best if not the only 
chance humanity has to survive is as slaves to my race.  A superior race 
with many but one key advantage that makes us superior to humanity, the 
ability to think ahead...﻿
